ANNOUNCE PLAY

Kegan Elected Head
Of Senior Class

Title to be Announced After.

PLAY HAS BEEN CHOSEN
, —
Interest to Be Aroused by
"Pop" Swindell
_Definite announcement of the
Barnstormers' choice for the varsity play is promised for next
Tuesday according to the officers
of the club. The selection of the
annual dramatic production invariably arouses - much interest
and conjecture among undergraduates and alumni.
True to Barnstormer tradition,
President Banks refused to'make
anything more than a cryptic
statement as to the nature of the
play.
"It is true," be said, '"that a
play has been- selected.- Announcement .sif title and details
will be fmrtficoining immediately
after: the 'club puts its approval
upon the reading committee's
choice."
"I can only say that'the production decided upon is one
which will give full range to typical Barnstornier dramatic style.
It is a rollicking farce of romance, adventure and love in a
unique setting. From the scenic
standpoint the play leaves little
to be desired: Colorful costumes,
exotic settings and tense situations abound.
"The cast is large and diversified, giving unusual opportunities
for 'the new and inexperienced
men which we hope to attract in
the November tryouts. Just wait!
This play is a knockout!"
Another announcement -to the
effect that Mr. Walter B. Swindell, Jr., coach and patron of the
Barnstormers, will address the
assembly of Thursday, November 22, will he welcomed by the
many ,undergraduates who know
him. He will especially endeavor
to arouse the interest of freshmen
and novices• in 'dramatics add
Urge - their attendance at the
Barnstormer Rally on the fallowing night, November 23.

made to enhance the prestige of'

results.

Gentlemen:
Since I first started to smoke, I
have always smoked cigarettes.
One day SHE said to me "Ed,
dear, why don't you smoke a r e. I
think thosb long straight-stemmed
pipes are so manly-looking."
So, naturally, I had to buy a longstemmed pipe and a can of well, well
call it "Blubs Mixture tobacco." Immediately with a certain feeling of
pride in my new pipe, I "lighted up"
and proceeded to have my tongue bitten. I tried almost every brand I had
ever heard o', but none satisfied me.
Sadly, I had to confess to IIER that
as a pipe smoker I was a good dietitian.
"Did you try Edgeworth?" she
asked. "That is what dad smokes,
and he's always smoked a pipe."
So I was forced to try Edgeworth,
and all that I can say is that if every
fellow that-has tried to accustom himself to a pipe,started with Edgeworth,
there would be very few that would go
. back to cigarettes.

MERCHANT

Definite announcement of the
Barnstormers',choice for the varsity play is promised for next
Tuesday according to the officers
of the club. The selection of the
annual dramatic production invariably arouses much interest
and conjecture among undergraduates and alumni.
True to Barnstormer tradition,
Pwsident Banks refused to'make
anything more than a cryptic
statement as to the nature of the
play.
"It is true," he said, "that a
play has been selected. Announcement of title and details
will be, forthconiing immediately
after the club puts its approval
upon the reading committee's
choice."
-"I can only say that the production decided upon is one
which will give full range to typical Barnstormer dramatic style.
It is a rollicking farce of romance, adventure and love in •a
unique setting. From the scenic
standpoint the play leaves little
to be desired. Colorful costumes,
exotic settings and tense situations abound.‘,
"The cast is large and diversified, giving unusual opportunities
for the new and inexperienced
men which we hope to attract in
the November tryouts. Just wait
This play is a knockout!"
Another announcement to the
effect that Mr. Walter B. Swindell, Jr., coach ail patron of the
Barnstormers, will address the
assembly of Thursday, November 22, will be welcomed by the
many undergraduates who know
him. He will especially endeavor
to arouse the interest of freshmen
and novices in dramatics and
urge their attendance at the
Barnstormer Rally on the followintrnight, November 23.

BARNSTORMERS TO
ANNOUNCE PLAY

Kegan Elected Head
Of Senior Class

Title to be Announced After.

PLAY HAS BEEN CHOSEN
, —
Interest to Be Aroused by
"Pop" Swindell
_Definite announcement of the
Barnstormers' choice for the varsity play is promised for next
Tuesday according to the officers
of the club. The selection of the
annual dramatic production invariably arouses - much interest
and conjecture among undergraduates and alumni.
True to Barnstormer tradition,
President Banks refused to'make
anything more than a cryptic
statement as to the nature of the
play.
"It is true," be said, '"that a
play has been- selected.- Announcement .sif title and details
will be fmrtficoining immediately
after: the 'club puts its approval
upon the reading committee's
choice."
"I can only say that'the production decided upon is one
which will give full range to typical Barnstornier dramatic style.
It is a rollicking farce of romance, adventure and love in a
unique setting. From the scenic
standpoint the play leaves little
to be desired: Colorful costumes,
exotic settings and tense situations abound.
"The cast is large and diversified, giving unusual opportunities
for 'the new and inexperienced
men which we hope to attract in
the November tryouts. Just wait!
This play is a knockout!"
Another announcement -to the
effect that Mr. Walter B. Swindell, Jr., coach and patron of the
Barnstormers, will address the
assembly of Thursday, November 22, will he welcomed by the
many ,undergraduates who know
him. He will especially endeavor
to arouse the interest of freshmen
and novices• in 'dramatics add
Urge - their attendance at the
Barnstormer Rally on the fallowing night, November 23.

A committee under Mr. Gordon
has charge of the arrangements
of this party and as planning a

The Barnstormers are projecting a triple-barreled policy this
year in addition to the usual aim
of surpassing the preceding
year's production. First, a definite program for enlisting the active support and interest of Barnstormers alumni will be pursued.
Secondly, greater efforts will be
made to enhance the prestige of'
Barnstormer production as a social .event. The Princeton Triangle Club's show has, always
been a high spot on the city's social calendar and the Barnstormers feel that concerted activity on
their part can produce similar
results.

Gentlemen:
Since I first started to smoke, I
have always smoked cigarettes.
One day SHE said to me "Ed,
dear, why don't you smoke a r e. I
think thosb long straight-stemmed
pipes are so manly-looking."
So, naturally, I had to buy a longstemmed pipe and a can of well, well
call it "Blubs Mixture tobacco." Immediately with a certain feeling of
pride in my new pipe, I "lighted up"
and proceeded to have my tongue bitten. I tried almost every brand I had
ever heard o', but none satisfied me.
Sadly, I had to confess to IIER that
as a pipe smoker I was a good dietitian.
"Did you try Edgeworth?" she
asked. "That is what dad smokes,
and he's always smoked a pipe."
So I was forced to try Edgeworth,
and all that I can say is that if every
fellow that-has tried to accustom himself to a pipe,started with Edgeworth,
there would be very few that would go
. back to cigarettes.

MERCHANT

Definite announcement of the
Barnstormers',choice for the varsity play is promised for next
Tuesday according to the officers
of the club. The selection of the
annual dramatic production invariably arouses much interest
and conjecture among undergraduates and alumni.
True to Barnstormer tradition,
Pwsident Banks refused to'make
anything more than a cryptic
statement as to the nature of the
play.
"It is true," he said, "that a
play has been selected. Announcement of title and details
will be, forthconiing immediately
after the club puts its approval
upon the reading committee's
choice."
-"I can only say that the production decided upon is one
which will give full range to typical Barnstormer dramatic style.
It is a rollicking farce of romance, adventure and love in •a
unique setting. From the scenic
standpoint the play leaves little
to be desired. Colorful costumes,
exotic settings and tense situations abound.‘,
"The cast is large and diversified, giving unusual opportunities
for the new and inexperienced
men which we hope to attract in
the November tryouts. Just wait
This play is a knockout!"
Another announcement to the
effect that Mr. Walter B. Swindell, Jr., coach ail patron of the
Barnstormers, will address the
assembly of Thursday, November 22, will be welcomed by the
many undergraduates who know
him. He will especially endeavor
to arouse the interest of freshmen
and novices in dramatics and
urge their attendance at the
Barnstormer Rally on the followintrnight, November 23.
